title: Definition of a Limit
content: The limit of a function f(x) as x approaches a is the value that f(x) approaches as x gets closer to a from both sides. Notation: limₓ→ₐ f(x).

title: One-Sided Limits
content: The left-hand limit is limₓ→ₐ⁻ f(x), and the right-hand limit is limₓ→ₐ⁺ f(x). The limit exists only if both one-sided limits exist and are equal.

title: Limits from Graphs and Tables
content: Use values approaching x = a from both sides to estimate limₓ→ₐ f(x). The function value at x = a does not affect the limit.

title: Algebraic Techniques for Evaluating Limits
content: If direct substitution results in an indeterminate form, simplify the expression by factoring, rationalizing, or combining terms before re-evaluating.

title: Limits Involving Infinity
content: If f(x) increases or decreases without bound as x approaches a, write limₓ→ₐ f(x) = ∞ or −∞. These indicate vertical asymptotes.

title: End Behavior and Horizontal Asymptotes
content: The limit of f(x) as x approaches ±∞ describes the end behavior. If limₓ→∞ f(x) = L, then y = L is a horizontal asymptote.

title: Continuity at a Point
content: A function f is continuous at x = a if limₓ→ₐ f(x) exists, f(a) is defined, and limₓ→ₐ f(x) = f(a).

title: Types of Discontinuity
content: Discontinuities can be removable (hole), jump (step), or infinite (asymptote). Identify based on the graph or algebraic form.

title: Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)
content: If f is continuous on [a, b] and N is between f(a) and f(b), then there exists at least one c in (a, b) such that f(c) = N.

title: Formal Definition of Limit (ε-δ, optional)
content: For every ε > 0 there exists δ > 0 such that if 0 < |x − a| < δ then |f(x) − L| < ε. (Not required for AP, but foundational for theory.)

title: Limit of sin(h)/h as h approaches 0
content: limₕ→0 sin(h)/h = 1. This is a fundamental limit used in the derivative of sine and must be memorized.

title: Limit of (1 − cos(h))/h as h approaches 0
content: limₕ→0 (1 − cos(h))/h = 0. This limit is also used when deriving the derivative of cosine.

title: Common Trigonometric Limits Summary
content: Key trig limits: limₓ→0 sin(x)/x = 1, limₓ→0 (1 − cos(x))/x = 0, limₓ→0 tan(x)/x = 1. These support derivative definitions.

title: Limit of sin(h)/h as h approaches 0
content: limₕ→0 sin(h)/h = 1. This is a fundamental limit used in the derivative of sine and must be memorized.

title: Limit of (1 − cos(h))/h as h approaches 0
content: limₕ→0 (1 − cos(h))/h = 0. This limit is also used when deriving the derivative of cosine.

title: Common Trigonometric Limits Summary
content: Key trig limits: limₓ→0 sin(x)/x = 1, limₓ→0 (1 − cos(x))/x = 0, limₓ→0 tan(x)/x = 1. These support derivative definitions.

title: Limit of ln(1 + x)/x as x approaches 0
content: limₓ→0 ln(1 + x)/x = 1. This limit is essential for defining the derivative of ln(x) and understanding natural log growth near x = 0.

title: Definition of the Derivative (Limit Form)
content: The derivative of f at x = a is defined as f'(a) = limₕ→0 [f(a + h) − f(a)] / h, if this limit exists.

title: Interpretation of Derivative as Slope
content: The derivative f'(a) represents the slope of the tangent line to the graph of f at x = a.

title: Derivative as Instantaneous Rate of Change
content: The derivative f'(a) gives the instantaneous rate of change of f with respect to x at x = a, such as velocity or growth rate.

title: Differentiability and Continuity
content: If a function is differentiable at x = a, then it is continuous at x = a. But a function can be continuous without being differentiable.

title: Graphical Non-Differentiability
content: A function may fail to be differentiable at a point due to a corner, cusp, vertical tangent, or discontinuity.

title: Power Rule for Derivatives
content: If f(x) = x^n, then f'(x) = n·x^(n−1), for all real n.

title: Constant and Constant Multiple Rules
content: The derivative of a constant is 0. The derivative of c·f(x) is c·f'(x).

title: Sum and Difference Rules
content: The derivative of f(x) ± g(x) is f'(x) ± g'(x).

title: Product Rule
content: If h(x) = f(x)·g(x), then h'(x) = f'(x)g(x) + f(x)g'(x).

title: Quotient Rule
content: If h(x) = f(x)/g(x), then h'(x) = [f'(x)g(x) − f(x)g'(x)] / [g(x)]².

title: Chain Rule
content: If y = f(g(x)), then dy/dx = f'(g(x))·g'(x). Take the derivative of the outer function, then multiply by the derivative of the inner function.

title: Power Chain Rule (Generalized Power Rule)
content: If y = [u(x)]^n, then dy/dx = n[u(x)]^(n−1) · u'(x).

title: Derivatives of Trigonometric Functions
content: d/dx [sin x] = cos x, d/dx [cos x] = −sin x, d/dx [tan x] = sec²x, etc. Know all six derivatives.

title: Derivatives of Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
content: d/dx [e^x] = e^x, d/dx [a^x] = a^x ln(a), d/dx [ln x] = 1/x, d/dx [log_b(x)] = 1/(x ln b).

title: Implicit Differentiation
content: When a function is not explicitly solved for y, differentiate both sides with respect to x, treating y as a function of x (use dy/dx when differentiating y).

title: Differentiating Inverse Functions
content: If f and f⁻¹ are inverses, then [f⁻¹]'(b) = 1 / f'(a), where f(a) = b. This is used to find derivatives of inverse trig and log functions.

title: Logarithmic Differentiation
content: To differentiate complex expressions like y = x^x or y = (f(x))^g(x), take the natural log of both sides and then differentiate implicitly.

title: Higher-Order Derivatives
content: The second derivative is the derivative of the first derivative: f''(x) = d²y/dx². Higher-order derivatives describe concavity, jerk, and more.

title: Notation for Derivatives
content: Common notations include f'(x), dy/dx, d²y/dx², Leibniz form, and prime notation. Know how to interpret each.

title: Tangent Line and Linear Approximation
content: The tangent line at x = a is L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x − a). This line can approximate values of f near x = a.

title: Differentials and Estimation
content: dy = f'(x)dx estimates the change in y for a small change dx in x. Useful for approximations using derivatives.

title: Instantaneous Velocity and Acceleration
content: If s(t) is position, then v(t) = s'(t) is velocity, and a(t) = s''(t) is acceleration. Units follow the context.

title: Speed and Direction of Motion
content: Speed is |v(t)|. An object changes direction when v(t) = 0 and a(t) ≠ 0. Positive v(t) means moving forward.

title: Mean Value Theorem (MVT)
content: If f is continuous on [a, b] and differentiable on (a, b), then there exists c such that f'(c) = [f(b) − f(a)] / (b − a).

title: Rolle's Theorem
content: If f is continuous on [a, b], differentiable on (a, b), and f(a) = f(b), then there is c in (a, b) with f'(c) = 0.

title: Increasing and Decreasing Intervals
content: If f'(x) > 0, f is increasing; if f'(x) < 0, f is decreasing. Use sign chart of f' to analyze intervals.

title: Critical Points and Extrema
content: Critical points occur where f'(x) = 0 or undefined. Use first derivative test or second derivative test to classify extrema.

title: Concavity and Inflection Points
content: If f''(x) > 0, the graph is concave up. If f''(x) < 0, concave down. Inflection points occur where concavity changes.

title: Optimization Problems
content: To solve optimization problems: define a function to maximize/minimize, find critical points, and test endpoints or extrema.

title: First Derivative Test
content: To determine if a critical point is a local max or min, check the sign of f'(x) before and after the point. If f' changes from + to −, it's a local max; − to + is a local min.

title: Second Derivative Test
content: If f'(c) = 0 and f''(c) > 0, then f has a local minimum at x = c. If f''(c) < 0, then f has a local maximum. If f''(c) = 0, the test is inconclusive.

title: Sketching Graphs Using Derivatives
content: Use f', f'' sign charts to determine increasing/decreasing intervals, extrema, concavity, and inflection points. Combine to sketch function behavior.

title: Solving Related Rates Problems
content: 1. Identify all changing quantities. 2. Relate them with an equation. 3. Differentiate implicitly with respect to time. 4. Plug in values and solve for the unknown rate.

title: Interpreting Units of Derivatives
content: If y = f(x), then f'(x) has units of output per input. For example, if f(x) is distance in meters and x is time in seconds, then f'(x) is in m/s.

title: Euler’s Method for Approximating Solutions
content: Euler’s Method approximates a solution to a differential equation dy/dx = f(x, y) using: yₙ₊₁ = yₙ + h·f(xₙ, yₙ), where h is the step size.

title: Interpretation of Small Changes Using Differentials
content: The differential dy = f'(x)·dx approximates how much y changes for a small change dx in x. Useful for error estimation and linearization.

title: Estimating Error Using Differentials
content: To estimate the error in a quantity, use dy = f'(x)·dx as an approximation of the change in f. This is useful in measurement problems.

title: Newton’s Method for Approximating Roots
content: Newton’s Method estimates roots of f(x) = 0 by iterating: xₙ₊₁ = xₙ − f(xₙ)/f'(xₙ). Requires an initial guess x₀ and uses tangent lines to converge to a root.

title: Antiderivative and Indefinite Integral
content: An antiderivative F of f satisfies F'(x) = f(x). The general antiderivative is written ∫f(x) dx = F(x) + C.

title: Basic Rules for Indefinite Integrals
content: ∫xⁿ dx = xⁿ⁺¹ / (n+1) + C (n ≠ −1), ∫1/x dx = ln|x| + C, ∫e^x dx = e^x + C, etc.

title: Integration as Area Under the Curve
content: The definite integral ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx represents the net area between f(x) and the x-axis from x = a to x = b.

title: Definition of the Definite Integral (Limit of Riemann Sums)
content: The definite integral is defined as limₙ→∞ ∑ f(xᵢ*)·Δx, partitioning [a, b] into subintervals. This formalizes area accumulation.

title: Left, Right, and Midpoint Riemann Sums
content: Approximate ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx using left endpoints (LRAM), right endpoints (RRAM), or midpoints (MRAM).

title: Trapezoidal Rule for Estimating Integrals
content: The trapezoidal approximation is (Δx / 2)·[f(x₀) + 2f(x₁) + ... + 2f(xₙ₋₁) + f(xₙ)]. More accurate than LRAM/RRAM.

title: Properties of Definite Integrals
content: Includes: ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx = −∫ᵇₐ f(x) dx, ∫ₐᵃ f(x) dx = 0, and linearity: ∫ₐᵇ [cf(x) ± g(x)] dx = c∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx ± ∫ₐᵇ g(x) dx.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1
content: If F(x) = ∫ₐˣ f(t) dt, then F'(x) = f(x). This links integration and differentiation.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 2
content: If f is continuous on [a, b], then ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx = F(b) − F(a), where F is any antiderivative of f.

title: Average Value of a Function
content: The average value of f on [a, b] is (1 / (b − a)) · ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx.

title: u-Substitution for Integration
content: To evaluate ∫f(g(x))g'(x) dx, let u = g(x), then rewrite the integral in terms of u and du.

title: Integration by Parts
content: Use ∫u·dv = uv − ∫v·du to integrate products of functions. Choose u and dv so that du and v are simpler to work with.

title: Trigonometric Integrals
content: Integrals involving sin(x), cos(x), tan(x), etc., often use identities such as sin²x = (1−cos2x)/2 to simplify before integrating.

title: Trigonometric Substitution
content: To integrate expressions like √(a² − x²), use x = a·sinθ. This simplifies the integrand using trig identities.

title: Partial Fraction Decomposition
content: To integrate rational functions, express them as a sum of simpler fractions: e.g., 1/[(x+1)(x+2)] = A/(x+1) + B/(x+2), then integrate term-by-term.

title: Improper Integrals (Infinite Bounds or Discontinuities)
content: An improper integral like ∫₁^∞ (1/x²) dx is defined as a limit: lim_{t→∞} ∫₁^t (1/x²) dx. Also includes integrals with vertical asymptotes.

title: L'Hôpital’s Rule for Indeterminate Forms
content: If lim f(x)/g(x) gives 0/0 or ∞/∞, and both f and g are differentiable, then lim f(x)/g(x) = lim f'(x)/g'(x), provided the latter exists.

title: Area and Arc Length in Parametric Form
content: For parametric curves x(t), y(t), the arc length is ∫ₐᵇ √[(dx/dt)² + (dy/dt)²] dt. Area is ∫ₐᵇ y(t)·x'(t) dt.

title: Area Between Two Curves
content: The area between f(x) and g(x) from x = a to x = b is ∫ₐᵇ |f(x) − g(x)| dx, assuming f and g are continuous.

title: Volume by Disk Method
content: The volume of a solid of revolution about the x-axis is V = π∫ₐᵇ [f(x)]² dx.

title: Volume by Washer Method
content: For rotating region between y = f(x) and y = g(x), volume is V = π∫ₐᵇ ([f(x)]² − [g(x)]²) dx.

title: Volume by Shell Method
content: When revolving around the y-axis: V = 2π∫ₐᵇ x·f(x) dx.

title: Distance Traveled from Velocity Function
content: If v(t) is velocity, then distance = ∫ₐᵇ |v(t)| dt. Net displacement = ∫ₐᵇ v(t) dt.

title: Position from Velocity (Initial Value)
content: Given v(t) and initial position s₀, position is s(t) = s₀ + ∫₀ᵗ v(x) dx.

title: Accumulation Function (Total Change)
content: For a rate of change r(t), total accumulated quantity from t = a to t = b is ∫ₐᵇ r(t) dt.

title: Average Value of a Quantity Over Time
content: The average of f(t) on [a, b] is (1 / (b − a)) ∫ₐᵇ f(t) dt.

title: Improper Integrals (Infinite Limits or Discontinuity)
content: An integral is called improper if it involves infinite bounds or discontinuities. Examples include ∫ₐ^∞ f(x) dx and ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx where f is undefined at a point in [a, b]. These are defined via limits. The integral converges if the corresponding limit exists.

title: Polar Coordinates
content: A point in the plane can be described in polar coordinates as (r, θ), where r is the distance from the origin and θ is the angle from the positive x-axis.

title: Converting Between Polar and Cartesian Coordinates
content: To convert: x = r·cos(θ), y = r·sin(θ); r = √(x² + y²), θ = arctan(y/x).

title: Area in Polar Coordinates
content: The area bounded by a polar curve r(θ) from θ = a to b is given by A = ½ ∫ₐᵇ [r(θ)]² dθ.

title: Definition of Differential Equation
content: A differential equation is an equation involving a function and its derivatives. It describes how a quantity changes.

title: Separable Differential Equations
content: A differential equation is separable if it can be written as dy/dx = f(x)·g(y). The solution is found by separating variables and integrating both sides.

title: Slope Fields (Direction Fields)
content: A slope field is a graphical representation of a differential equation by drawing small line segments with slope dy/dx at various points.

title: Particular Solution with Initial Condition
content: To find a particular solution of a differential equation, use the general solution and substitute the initial condition (x₀, y₀) to solve for C.

title: Logistic Growth Model
content: A population model where growth slows as it approaches carrying capacity: dy/dt = r·y·(1 − y/K). The solution involves a logistic curve.

title: Exponential Growth and Decay Model
content: For a quantity y(t) that grows or decays at a rate proportional to its current value, dy/dt = ky. The solution is y(t) = y₀·e^(kt), where k > 0 indicates growth and k < 0 indicates decay.

title: Definition of a Sequence
content: A sequence is an ordered list of numbers defined by a rule. It can be written explicitly (e.g., aₙ = 1/n) or recursively (e.g., a₁ = 1, aₙ = aₙ₋₁ + 2).

title: Limit of a Sequence
content: The limit of a sequence aₙ as n approaches infinity is the value L such that for any ε > 0, there exists N where |aₙ − L| < ε for all n > N. If such L exists, the sequence converges.

title: Monotonic and Bounded Sequences
content: A sequence that is both monotonic (increasing or decreasing) and bounded must converge. This is known as the Monotonic Sequence Theorem.

title: Definition of Infinite Series
content: An infinite series is the sum of the terms of an infinite sequence: ∑aₙ = a₁ + a₂ + a₃ + .... The sequence of partial sums Sₙ determines convergence.

title: Geometric Series Test
content: A geometric series ∑arⁿ converges if |r| < 1, with sum a / (1 - r). If |r| ≥ 1, the series diverges.

title: nth-Term Divergence Test
content: If limₙ→∞ aₙ ≠ 0, then ∑aₙ diverges. If limₙ→∞ aₙ = 0, this does not guarantee convergence.

title: p-Series Test
content: A p-series ∑1/nᵖ converges if p > 1, and diverges if p ≤ 1.

title: Comparison Test
content: If 0 ≤ aₙ ≤ bₙ and ∑bₙ converges, then ∑aₙ converges. If aₙ ≥ bₙ ≥ 0 and ∑bₙ diverges, then ∑aₙ diverges.

title: Limit Comparison Test
content: If limₙ→∞ aₙ/bₙ = c > 0 (finite), and ∑bₙ converges or diverges, then ∑aₙ behaves the same.

title: Ratio Test
content: For ∑aₙ, compute L = limₙ→∞ |aₙ₊₁ / aₙ|. If L < 1, the series converges absolutely. If L > 1 or is infinite, it diverges. If L = 1, the test is inconclusive.

title: Alternating Series Test (Leibniz)
content: An alternating series ∑(−1)ⁿaₙ converges if aₙ is decreasing and limₙ→∞ aₙ = 0.

title: Absolute vs Conditional Convergence
content: A series ∑aₙ converges absolutely if ∑|aₙ| converges. If ∑aₙ converges but ∑|aₙ| diverges, it converges conditionally.

title: Taylor Series Definition
content: The Taylor series for a function f(x) centered at a is ∑[f⁽ⁿ⁾(a)/n!](x−a)ⁿ. If a = 0, it is the Maclaurin series.

title: Radius and Interval of Convergence
content: For a power series ∑aₙ(x−c)ⁿ, the radius of convergence R determines where the series converges. Use ratio test to find R, then check endpoints for interval.

title: Using Power Series to Approximate Functions
content: Functions can be approximated by truncating their Taylor series. For example, sin(x) ≈ x − x³/6 + x⁵/120 for small x.

title: Lagrange Error Bound for Taylor Approximation
content: The error in approximating f(x) with an n-th degree Taylor polynomial centered at a is bounded by |Rₙ(x)| ≤ [M / (n+1)!]·|x−a|ⁿ⁺¹, where M is the maximum of |f⁽ⁿ⁺¹⁾(z)| for z between a and x.

title: Definition of Parametric Equations
content: Parametric equations express a curve using a third variable t: x = f(t), y = g(t). These represent a path in the xy-plane.

title: First Derivative for Parametric Functions
content: If x = f(t) and y = g(t), then dy/dx = (dy/dt) / (dx/dt), provided dx/dt ≠ 0.

title: Second Derivative for Parametric Functions
content: The second derivative d²y/dx² = d/dt(dy/dx) ÷ dx/dt. It measures concavity of parametric curves.

title: Arc Length of Parametric Curves
content: The arc length from t = a to t = b is ∫ₐᵇ √[(dx/dt)² + (dy/dt)²] dt.

title: Vector-Valued Function Definition
content: A vector-valued function is written as **r(t)** = ⟨x(t), y(t)⟩ and describes motion in the plane with position depending on time.

title: Velocity, Speed, and Acceleration in Vectors
content: Given r(t) = ⟨x(t), y(t)⟩, velocity = r'(t), speed = |r'(t)| = √[(dx/dt)² + (dy/dt)²], acceleration = r''(t).
